results.notes:
Two fruiting bodies growing in mixed deciduous woods of oak, beech, maple and hickory.
> The prominently appendiculate margins for fbs in this section was a pleasant surprise — it’s not a common occurence as the material is readily lost
> Marginal striation became prominent post collection, especially after the UV fluff wore off
> The upper half of the stipe was moderately floccose
> The volval sack of one of the fb was distorted — perhaps a developmental anomaly
> The fb stained dull pink post collection, especially in the cap
> 1 fb (with the distorted volva) was preserved for RET

results.notes:
Growing just a few yards away from obs 245847 in mixed deciduous woods. Viscid & tacky caps; no partial veil/annulus; base of stipe with a bulb; the shape of volva at top of bulb appears to be consistent with subsect. Gemmatae.
I didn’t collect these as they were in poor shape/waterlogged and would not have survived a 6 hr trip to NEMF.

results.notes:
I haven’t seen this species for several years, so I welcome it back…
Several diminutive basidiocarps (in my experience, small habit is typical for this species) growing singly in a line in sandy soil on a mossy ridge along a dirt road under mature oaks and oak saplings and pitch pines.
The pores, cap & stipe surface and context not staining any color. The context is uniformly lemon yellow.
Chemical Tests: KOH = chocolate brown on cap pileipellis; amber brown on cap context. NH3 = instantly bright green, changing to medium brown in a few seconds on cap pileipellis; darker dingy yellow, resolving grayish on cap context.
FeSO4 = no apparent reaction on cap pileipellis or cap context.

DNA Results & Discussion (final update 9-Nov-17):
> A clean, contiguous, 782 bps long nrITS sequence was obtained for this material. In addition, the first 146 characters of the 5’ end of a nrLSU sequence were procured.
> A GenBank BLAST search of the ITS sequence gave the following top-scoring relevant hits (sorted by % similarity):
- Boletus subtomentosus voucher F:PRL5676MAN (accession #GQ166875; 881 bps long) collected from Cook County Forest Preserve/Sag Valley Division, Swallow Cliff Woods, Illinois = 830/830 = 100%
- Boletus cf. innixus voucher FH:MES232 (accession #FJ480443; 924 bps long) = 924/925 = 99.9%
- Xerocomus illudens voucher MB03-005 (accession #JQ003658; 782 bps long) = 780/782 = 99.7% similarity, no gaps
The remaining large number of hits with lower scores and % similarity are all members of Xerocomus or Phylloporus, as well as unidentified environmental samples.
> This bolete, without a question, is a member of the genus Xerocomus, as evidenced by the gross morphology, the nrITS sequence and the corresponding GenBank BLAST search hits. Analogous collections were made by me from different sites in the NJ Pine Barrens several years ago and posted to MO: obs 73652 and obs 74398. This entity is characterized by the small habit, variable degree of ridging/reticulation in the upper part of the stipe, a green ammonia reaction on the yellowish-brown cap cuticle and total lack of surface/context bluing. Dave W apparently collected the same species, albeit bruising pale blue on the pore surface, from two separate locations in Luzerne Co., PA (obs 249274 and obs 249357), as the nrITS sequence of one of his collections was 100% identical to 245956.
Xerocomus of North America has been in serious need of a deep taxonomic study supported by molecular characterization for way too long. The confusing “subtomentosus group” of NA consisting of X. subtomentosus itself (in the sense of NA authors), X. illudens, X. spacideus/ferrugienus (in the sense of NA authors) and X. tenax is particularly noteworthy in that regard as per the relevant discussion of M. Kuo and the new bolete book (BENA) by Bessette et al. There probably exist undescribed look-alikes that “conveniently” passed as the aforementioned taxa. The greatest challenge of such studies lies not in obtaining fresh, well-described and photographed samples or doing the lab work, or running in silico phylogenetic analyses, but in proper examination of holotypes and molecular typification of old vouchers necessary to connect and reconcile the named historic taxa with their modern species concepts.
With regard to the identification to species, IMO this is not X. subtomentosus (wrong NH3 reaction) or X. tenax (lack of coarse and widely-spaced reticulation). This leaves illudens and spacideus/ferrugineus as a questionable possibility, as far as formally published and recognized North American Xerocomus taxa are concerned.

results.notes:
These were found in grass under oak, at a spot where I also found T. alboater. It’s been quite dry but there were intermittent and occasionally heavy rainstorms over the weekend. This particular spot was still hard, but there was still some moisture caught in cup-like leaves, etc. There were no other mushrooms whatsoever except these boletes and the alboater, with the exception of a few amanitas that had just thrust up eggs. These specimens are probably 2-3 days old at the most, which is confirmed by the very undeveloped tube layer.

First off, this is a different mushroom than observation 244233 and observation 244343. There is almost no red on the cap and stipe was a pure yellow with orange tints but no real red or pink at all. The cap was also much more brown than red.

The context blued a deep indigo almost instantly – so fast that I had to cut it three times before being sure the flesh was yellow before it changed. The pores bruised a similar blue, but more slowly and eventually resolved to brown. The flesh resolves to brown as well. The tube layer is still extraordinarily thin, perhaps a 20th of the cap flesh, so that may play a role too. The texture is quite brittle as opposed to the firm but “cheese-like” texture of the cited observations.

The stipe are quite thick but not bulbous. Mycelium was white. There are few bug holes but their color is hard to determine because of the bluing. Possibly dark brown.

No smell of curry – just a very mild mushroom scent. No taste either.

HEIGHT: 11 cm
CAP WIDTH: 10 cm
CONTEXT: 17 mm
TUBES: 1 mm

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No reaction, or slowly red
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: Red. (A major “huh?”)
Ammonia on Pores: No reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow.
Ammonia on Cap Context: No reaction but slowly eliminated bluing
Ammonia on Stipe Context:No reaction but slowly eliminated bluing

KOH on Cap Skin: Orange.
KOH on Stipe Skin: Orange, but brighter.
KOH on Pores: Orange.
KOH on Cap Context: Orange.
KOH on Stipe Context: Orange.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Olive green.

UPDATE – I found older versions of what appears to be the same mushroom, growing in the same place three days later. New pictures have been added but no specimens of the older ones have been preserved.

results.notes: A young specimen showing the typical colors, but without the browning that eventually takes over the entire mushroom in age, and giving an impression of L. pseudosensibilis; however, that taxon doesn’t grow in the Pine Barrens. Note the uniform marble staining pattern of the cut context and brown tones in the stipe base context. Browning of the context elsewhere begins to show in 20-30 sec post sectioning. The faint reticulation at the apex is rather unusual.

results.notes:
FULIGO SEPTICA (L.) F.H. WIGG.
PHYSACACEAE, PHYSARALES. (SCRAMBLED-EGG SLIME, ФУЛИГО ГНИЛОСТНЫЙ).
Whitish soft mass looks as soft foam; it turns into dry dark chocolate-brown uneven crust. Odour is unpleasant.
Mushroom: 1×3 up to 4×10cm in plan and 1-3cm high, oval convex mass or a cover on branches and pine needles; it looks as foam with tiny globules or bubbles when young and soft and finally mushroom turns into fragile and loose dark chocolate brown or purplish black mass.
Habitat: rare kind in this location, single or small groups on rotten stumps or trunks or branches.
Edibility: no data
Season: June-August.

results.notes: This one has me totally stumped. Here’s what I know. A pair of side-by-side specimens fruiting in ground, primarily Oak-Hickory woods. One specimen appeared to have been disturbed, perhaps by an animal, since this is a seldom frequented area with little, if any, foot traffic. Cap: 6.5 cm. “warty” (see close-up image), fragile — falling apart easily when handled. Stipe: 4 cm. X 2 cm., spongy, not fragile or crumbly like cap. Flesh under cap and within stipe appeared to contain a rosy “juice” which stained surrounding materials when crushed, yet does not appear to come through the gills per se as with Lactarius milk; note the leaves in the in situ photo where one specimen was crushed. Strong unpleasant odor — hard to describe. KOH slowly yellow on cap. Obtained a white spore print.

results.notes:
Cortinarius violaceus (L.) Gray, Cortinariaceae, Agaricales. (Паутинник фиолетовый).
Cap: 5-9 cm, convex up to broadly convex, margins curved in and wavy when old, color is bright violet up to dark violet or dull grayish-purple; surface fine velvety and somewhat silky when dry or some slimy in wet weather.
Gills: attached and pinching out toward stalk, close to almost distant; narrow up to moderately broad with short and very short intermediate gills, color from bright violet up to dark violet or grayish-violet.
Veil: partial veil as white cotton at young mushroom.
Stalk: 5-10cm long with weak indistinct remnants of veil, 2-3.5cm thick, enlarged down often up to bulbous base, indistinct fibrous and somewhat hairy, irregular colored dull orange-brown with violet spots and lines, sometimes with violet top.
Edibility: good.
Habitat: rather rare kind, single, minor small group in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
July – September.

results.notes:
A very interesting collection of mild-tasting Tylopilus sp. Very similar-looking observations identified as T. variobrunneus include obs 49324, obs 73628, obs 213832, and my own obs 244395.
The most interesting feature of this bolete is the ornamentation on the stipe. It starts at the apex as elongated brown reticulation that gradually transitions into a dense network of brown ridges and dots/pruinosity down to the bottom of the stipe. When visualized under lens, the ridges with sharp “peaks” are ornamented with brown hyphal incrustations.
The exposed context stains pale reddish-brown in less than 1 min.

Chemical Tests:
KOH = blackish-maroon on pileipellis; pale yellow on oxidized context
NH3 = mahogany-brown in pileipellis; negative on oxidized context
FeSO4 = greenish-blue on pileipellis; slate-blue on oxidized context
These results are in partial agreement with those of T. variobrunneus reported in NAB

results.notes:
Pileus: 15-45+ cm across, often fusing laterally to make fruiting bodies 80+ cm across, circular, lobed, when young smooth and pale orangish, in age becoming red-orange to dark reddish and velvety to finely hairy, oldest areas brownish purplish and hairy, hairs white where actively growing, bruising dark red-brown and eventually turning dark purplish

Pore Surface: decurrent, white to off-white, instantly staining brown where touched, small circular pores (about 3 widely-spaced pores per mm), tubes up to 1cm long, sometimes exuding droplets of brownish-red water when young

Stipe: 10-20cm tall, 5-10+ cm thick, rudimentary, central, reddish brown

Flesh: 2-10+ cm thick, soft, spongy, wet (exudes brownish red liquid when squeezed), whitish to tan with darker growth rings, turning brown where exposed, after a couple weeks the whole mushroom begins to decompose and turns black, ending as black goo that quickly disappears

Odor: strong, unusual, musty, somewhat unpleasant

Spore Print: difficult to obtain, maybe white

Spores: smooth, elliptic, hyaline, with 1 or more oil droplets

Habitat: single to several, on ground, probably growing from two nearby 20-year-old buried oak stumps (hardwood mulch nearby, other nearby trees: Japanese maple, ornamental cherry tree, zelkova), season late July through August, prefers to fruit during hot and dry weather

results.notes: Lumpy, undulating, resupinate growth on a few fallen leaves in oak-hickory surroundings. White, darkening with age. Spongey, moist, flexible. results.notes:
All the same color or a mixed collection? The ones on the left come from the same patch where I’ve been finding the “bulbous type” bicolors all year. The ones on the right come from a different part of the park about half a mile away. The texture, taste, smell, context color, freedom from bugs, etc. are all very similar. But the decorations on the stipe… Are these a significant enough difference to suspect they are different species? Other bicolor-lookalikes have been found in between the two areas, and I know from experience that the two patches always contain these differences. (The Deer Browse patch varies in shade but is almost always a progression of powdery color changes going up or down, while the Lone Pine patch always has this streakiness).

FWIW, the ones on the left had a more pronounced smell than any I found earlier in the year, and it does have more of a “bouillon” aspect though I still wonder how much of that could be the power of suggestion. Consider the pallidoroseus possibility to be advanced a few percentage. The ones on the right did not have that smell.

Collections were made two days ago and the specimens have been held in the fridge. Chemical tests are not available for that reason. I did not observe any differences in the bluing characteristics, but by now it would be moot.

A NOTE ON LIGHTING: These were taken in full shade on a sunny morning (the west side of the house). I then increased the “exposure” to max on my computer. The mushroom colors match what my eyes see 100% despite the distorted shades on the underlying piece of paper.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_994/2016_DSC4325

Habitat: steep mountain slope, southwest aspect, mixed Fagus sylvatica and Picea abies wood, under beeches; associated with Yellow bird’s-nest (Hypopitys monotropa), Yellow coralroot (Corallorhiza trifida), Red Helleborine (Cephalanthera rubra) and Broad-leaved helleborine (Epipactis helleborine aggr), in shade, calcareous ground, on places with little or no ground vegetation, partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitations ~3.000 mm/year, average temperature 2-4 deg C, elevation approximately 1.200 m (4.000 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: loose hummus soil.

Place: Upper Trenta valley, near Vršič pass road, southwest slopes of Mt. Prisank, 2.547 m (8.357 feet), East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: This achlorophyllous (having no chlorophyll), mycoheterotrophic (getting at least some part of its food from parasitism upon fungi) (not saprophytes! as frequently stated, see: Ref.:8), Euro-Asiatic plant, mostly living underground, has disappeared already from many places in Europe. O. Sebald et al. (1998) reports about a place in Baden-Württemberg, DE, which has been occasionally monitoring now for almost 80 years. Sources from 1935 talk about “thousands of blooming plants”. The place was extensively studied again in 1996. Population found counted only 18 blooming plants. Drawings of the plants from 1935 show large groups of plants with up to 15 flowers per stem. In 1996 ten of 18 plants found had only a single flower and the highest number of flowers found was three – on a single plant. The main reason for this drastic decline seems to be nitrogenized soil through polluted air. Obviously no local protection means can help against polluted air.

Protected by Uredba o zavarovanih prosto živečih rastlinskih vrstah, poglavje A, Uradni list RS, št. 46/2004 (Regulation of protected wild plants, chapter A, Official Gazette of Republic Slovenia, no. 46/2004), (2004). Pravilnik o uvrstitvi ogroženih rastlinskih in živalskih vrst v rdeči seznam, Uradni list RS, št. 82/2002 (Regulation of enlisting of endangered plant and animal species onto Red List, Official Gazette of Republic Slovenia, no. 82/2002) (2002) marked by “E” representing a critically endangered species.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes:
Tricholoma saponaceum (Fr.) P. Kumm. Tricholomataceae, Agaricales.
(Рядовка мыльная)
Light olive-gray mushroom with a wavy cap and a strong stalk.
Cap: 4-10cm wide, light gray with olive or brownish tint (minor lemon) and irregular colored, smooth, wide cone or bell-shaped when young, then convex or broadly convex (sometimes with indistinct wide knob or irregular shape when crowded) up to almost flat or sunken and broken with radial cracks when old. Margin is curved in for convex caps and wavy when old.
Flesh is white and thick. Odor is unpleasant as a bad soap has.
Gills: attached and often pinching out to the stalk, narrow, close, white or cream-white up to brownish-white when dried or old.
Stalk: 4-8cm long, white 1.5-3cm thick, enlarged toward down sometimes bulbous for young units and some fibrous and brownish-white for old ones.
Habitat: small groups or clusters scattered in pine-tree forest with some birches.
Edibility: local people do not gather this kind because bad smelt, published that edible after fermentation.
Season: June – September.

See also obs 246380 and obs 246394 of other mild-tasting Tylopilus species from the same woods.

KOH = instantly bright yellow on context; blotter flesh dinghy yellow
NH3 = instantly light yellow on context
FeSO4 = slate-blue on context

results.notes:
Location: White Rock Campground
Habitat: Open oak woods with Rhododendron.
Substrate: Well decayed moss-covered log.

I was struck at some 20 yards away by the beautiful orange pseudoaethalium on a moss-covered, well-rotted log. It had apparently formed overnight. I coillected it and watched it got progressively darker. It turned tan by evening.

One mystery is that some pseudoaethalia turned oily black – and even stained my clothes. It seems that the normal progression is from orange to tan sporangia full of dry, tan spores, which then are released. I’m not sure why some bodies were oily black.

results.notes: I found these yesterday growing scattered and in small clusters gregariously in grass between 2 large red oaks. There were probably at least 50 of them there. The pores were small and bruised dull blue quickly and then faded to dull grey before fading to brown. The stem was yellow beneath a layer of pinkish-red pruina that sometimes broke into patches. The stem also had the same staining reaction on the surface. The outer layer of many of the stems had split and peeled back. The cap surface was dry, slightly roughened and stained brown. The largest fruiting bodies had cap diameters of about 5 cm and total heights between 6 and 7 cm. The context in the cap and stem was yellow, dense, firm, sticky to slimy and did not bruise. The odor was slightly sweet and reminded me of some sort of multivitamin I’d taken before. The taste was somewhat sweet and fruity and also reminded me of some sort of multivitamin. The cap surface tasted the same but not as strongly when licked. NH4OH flashed blue green on the cap before resolving to yellowish-brown, negative on context, slightly yellowish on stem. KOH reddish-brown on cap, negative on context, yellowish-brown on stem. FeSO4 dull grey on cap, negative to grey on context, grey on stem. Growing in same spot as obs 265035.

results.notes:
Tricholoma saponaceum (Fr.) P. Kumm., Tricholomataceae, Agaricales.
(Рядовка мыльная)
Cap: 4-10cm wide, light gray with olive or brownish tint (minor lemon) and irregular colored, smooth, wide cone or bell-shaped when young, then convex or broadly convex up to almost flat with wide knob, often irregular shape in plan. Margin is curved in for convex caps and wavy when old.
Flesh is white and thick. Odor is unpleasant as a bad soap has.
Gills: attached and often pinching out to the stalk, narrow, close, white or cream-white up to brownish-white when dried or old.
Stalk: 4-8cm long, white 1.5-3cm thick, enlarged toward down sometimes bulbous for young units and some fibrous and brownish-white for old ones.
Habitat: small groups or clusters scattered in pine-tree forest with some birches.
Edibility: rather rare kind in this location; published that edible after fermentation.
Season: June – September.

results.notes:
Not an ideal situation here: I dug these out of a pile of pine needles and yard clippings that a neighbor had put on the side of the road. In other words, I have know idea about the initial location from which these very large fruiting bodies were extirpated. They were piled up as trash. I’m guessing they came from the backyard. There were bits of red mulch lodged in the base of the larger one’s stipe.
That said, whatever they are, I’ve never seen anything like them around here. They are hefty, around the size of a robust bolete. The stipes are solid and the interior is white. They are scaled, almost Leccinum-like, and the one that appears to have the whole stipe intact has a pointed radicle-like base. The gills are notched. As they have been manipulated and sun-blanched, I don’t know the extent to which they have changed.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 144109262 on December 10, 2022.

results.notes:
Pseudoboletus parasiticus (Bull.) Sutara
Cap: 3-6cm convex up to broadly convex; dull yellowish-brown, indistinct radial streaked with brown spots along margin. Flesh is whitish up to yellowish-white, weak unpleasant radecky smell.
Tubes: descending, colour dull purplish-brown. Sells are slightly extended with radial orientation.
Stalk: 7-10cm long, 0.7-1cm thick and light yellow with reddish-brown net ornamentation and greenish colouring under a cap, top half with white flesh, down part is dull yellow up to greenish-blue bruising near a base.
Habitat: rare kind, single in pine-tree forest with rare elm. It was 5-10cm near many Lycoperdon perlatum stumps after a former mushrooming.
Edibility: not edible.
Season: July – August.

results.notes:
Limacella illinita (Fr.) Maire (Лимацелла масляная)
This is only light yellow ringless Limacella kind in this region. It has clear feature: the older, the lighter a cap up to almost white with yellowish shadow.
Cap: 4-7cm wide when adult, much slimy; bell-shaped, convex as 1/3 of a ball up to almost flat, sometimes with indistinct knob, sometimes radial grooved, smooth; colour changed from light orange-yellow up to dull yellow, then yellowish-white; the cap top is darker.
Veil: at very young mushroom, much slimy.
Flesh is white, thin and fragile.
Gills: free or almost free, close up to crowded, white up yellowish-white when died. Odour is weak and pleasant.
Stalk: 7-12cm long, 0.6-1cm thick, slimy when young, weakly enlarged down; light yellow or yellowish-white, sometimes slightly dull orange hairy.
Habitat: rare small group or single scattered in wet places in pine-tree forest with rare birches and aspen (very rare in dry summer, typical, when unusual rainy year).
Edibility: edible.
Season: June-August.

results.notes:
Notes last updated/edited on 15-Dec-18
This collection was found at the NJMA foray by Ms. Kyoko Okabe. I am leaning toward Caloboletus sp., but Butyriboletus peckii (the current name) is a conceivable possibility as per the information in North America Boletes(2000, as Boletus peckii) and Boletes of Eastern North America (2016), both by Bessette-Roody-Bessette.

Collection Description:
Pileus: 4.5-5.7 cm wide, 1.3-1.5 cm thick in the middle when measured from the surface to the juncture with the stipe, pulvinate/cushion-shaped, margin with a narrow band of sterile tissue; surface dry, slightly subtomentose to smooth and glabrous, not staining when rubbed, dull pinkish-red (near oac498 to oac518 to oac539 when fresh), fading somewhat over time post collection, but still retaining the original hue even after drying/preservation; context whitish to pale yellow, soft (with a marshmallow consistency/texture), readily bluing upon exposure to air; odor fungal but with a rancid note; taste bitter.
Pore Surface: buff-yellow to dull medium yellow, becoming grayish/dingy yellow (younger fb) to olivaceus-buff post collection (older fb), instantly bluing when bruised and then gradually resolving pale brown; pores circular and minute, 3-4 per mm; tubes 5-7 mm at the widest point (near the stipe), same color as the pores surface, bruising blue when cut
Stipe: 6.0-6.7 cm long (measured in sections), 1 cm thick at apex, 1.4-1.8 cm thick at the base, curved and enlarged downward, dry, solid, with a bright lemon yellow apex, dark rose-red to pinkish-red directly below to the middle and brownish (possibly due to handling) in the bottom section, distinctly reticulate from the apex down to the mid-length, at which point the reticulation becomes a network of shallow vertical ridges, quickly transition to a smooth surface toward the bottom section; the reticulation is yellow in the apex and red below, staining bluish and then brownish upon handling; the base section is covered with a whitish coating/bloom; mycelium is possibly white; context is whitish to pale yellow in the upper section (just like in the cap) and readily staining blue upon exposure to air, reddish to deep raspberry red below and dingy yellow in the base.
Spore print: a light coating of spores was directly deposited on a glass slide, but its color could not be visualized against a white background; however, the color appears to be olivaceus-brown when the slide is held up against natural light.
Spore measurements: [20/1/1], L x W = (9.1-) 9.3-11.2 x (3.3-) 3.5-4.0 μm in lateral (dorsi-ventral) view; L’ x W’ = 10.3 × 3.7 μm; Q = (2.60-) 2.67-2.94 (-3.00); Q’ = 2.82. Not amyloid, not dextrinoid, and light greenish-buff in Melzer’s; equilateral and generally oblong in face-view (dorsal/ventral) and somewhat to subtly inequilateral and approximately oblong in lateral-view, smooth and thin-walled, cylindrical based on the Q-ratio range.
Smith and Thiers (1971) list spore lengths reported by Peck as 0.00035-0.00040" (8.9-10.2 μm). After re-examining Peck’s type, they updated the spore measurements to 9-12 (-13) x 3.5-5 μm. Bessette’s NAB gives spore measurements as 10-14 × 3.5 -5 μm.
Macrochemical tests: KOH = dingy yellow/mustard yellow on pileipellis, erased bluing then pale orange on cap context; NH3 = dingy yellow/mustard yellow on pileipellis, erased bluing then pale yellow on cap context; FeSO4 = gray to bluish gray on pileipellis, erased bluing then bluish-gray on blotted cap context (difficult to interpret).
Habitat: The collector couldn’t remember the particulars of the habitat, but the boletes grew by the stream. I recall that area being surrounded by deciduous trees, including oak and beech.

DNA Sequencing Results (last updated on 20-Dec-18):
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence of 1443 bps was obtained from this voucher. There is a single ambiguous character, a “Y”, corresponding to either “C” or “T”. A BLASTn search of the first 961 characters (to the LR5 primer) did not return any matching or very close hits. When the search results were sorted by % identity, there was no clear indication of this sequence clading in Caloboletus. However, a phylogram built in GenBank from representative well-identified accession associated with a number of genera of yelllow- or red-pored bluing boletes from this hit list gave a clear indication of the association with Caloboletus.
Since B. peckii was not on this hit list, I aligned the sole published nrLSU sequence of the alleged collection of peckii (accession JQ326999) with that of MO246697 separately. JQ32699 is only 649 nucleotides long, and it overlays with the 270—>918 bp fragment of my sequence. Even though there are no gaps, the two sequences are 23 bases off, corresponding to only 96.0% similarity. Obviously these two entities are not conspecific.
> A clean and contiguous 913 bp TEF-1-alpha sequence was also obtained from this voucher. There are 6 ambiguous characters: two “Y” (C/T) and four “R” (A/G). Four of these (2 x “R” & 2 x “Y”) are present in the 610 bps region circumscribed by the EF1-983F and EF1-1567R primers.
Other than the few ambiguities present here, this sequence is a perfect match to the corresponding regions in those of obs 286214 (my other NJ collection) and Robert G.‘s obs 283600 from CT, making these three collections conspecific. These three sequences finally published in GenBank on 10-Dec-18 (MH318614, MH337297, and MH347321).
The only previously published TEF-1 accession of the alleged collection of peckii (JQ327026) is 1117 bps long. Its alignment with MH318614 (this obsie) revealed that common overlap is only 621 bps long. There are a total of 58 mismatching positions, corresponding to the very low similarity of 91%.
A BLASTn search of a 610 bps sequence fragment (the region between & including the EF1-983F and EF1-1567R primers) produced a hit list from which a phylogram was built in GenBank to probe the phylogenetic relationships. It’s been annotated for clarity and uploaded to this post.

Discussion:
> Once a common taxon, nowadays Boletus peckii Frost in Peck is an infrequently encountered North American bolete.1 Interestingly, the aforementioned field guides by Bessette et al. draw a morphological parallel with Baorangia bicolor, the only significant difference between the two being the reticulation usually seen in peckii and its unpalatable taste.
> In 2014, B. peckii, along with a number of other bolete taxa from Boletus sect. Calopodes Fr. emend. Lannoy & Estadès, was transferred by A. Vizzini into Caloboletus Vizzini gen. nov.2 Morphologically, it differs from the typical members of Caloboletus (now delimited by a number published molecular studies) by the color of its cap; however, its inherently bitter taste is one of key defining traits of this genus.
> In 2015, Zhao et al. transferred C. peckii into Butyriboletus D. Arora & J.L. Frank based on the phylogenetic analysis of the aforementioned alleged peckii collection, known as “voucher 3959”.3 According to N. Siegel (see his comment below) and Reference #1, voucher 3959 – collected by R. Petersen in Tennessee in 1963 – could very well be a misidentified collection of Boletus speciosus or perhaps another member of North American Butyriboletus.
> In terms of gross morphology, MO246697 is a very good match to the original description of B. peckii.4 The bitter taste, the yellow pore surface bruising blue, the reticulated stipe, and the bluing of the flesh all point to Caloboletus as the likely generic placement for MO246697. Furthermore, the nrLSU and TEF-1 sequences of MO246697 do not match the corresponding molecular data of Petersen’s peckii voucher. The well-document record of MO246697 and the apparent absence of any pictures and/or a description of voucher 3959, further make the identity of Petersen’s collection of peckii questionable. Phylogenetically, MO246697 shows a strong affinity to Caloboletus. Analysis of the TEF-1 sequence in GenBank/BLASTn is attached to this post.
The two plausible conclusions drawn from this discussion are that MO246697 is Boletus peckii and that Vizzini was right in making peckii a member of Caloboletus based on the morphology alone.
References:
1 http://iucn.ekoo.se/iucn/species_view/223743/
2 http://www.indexfungorum.org/...
3 https://www.researchgate.net/...
4 https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/...

results.notes:
An NJMA foray collection. The two basidiomes likely collected separately (and not by me) in deciduous woods of beech oak and other hardwoods, but the morphology suggests it’s very likely to be the same species.
Note the large elongate/radicating bulbs with widely spaced rings of recurving scales. I don’t think the bulbs were collected in their entirety, as the tips appear to have been broken off or cut off. The overall shape is evocative of A. magniradix (RET has collected this taxon in MW in the past + it was collected at the NJMA foray there last year – see obs 210733), however, the shape of UV warts reported for that species is different. The odor of intact basidiomes was of pure chlorine (smelled under the cap). Both plants have been preserved for RET.
The larger fb had an unexpanded cap of 8 cm wide (measured in the evening before dehydration) and a stipe of 16 cm long. The stipe was 2 cm wide in the apex and 1.5 cm wide in the narrowest section just above the bulb. The latter was 3.2 cm wide and 7 cm long.

results.notes:
Laccaria Berk. & Broome (Лаковица розовая)
Small purplish-red mushroom with long fibrous stalk
Cap: 1.5-3.0 cm wide, bell-shaped or cone-shaped when young, convex up to almost flat with slightly sunken center, purplish-red or brick red, smooth and some radial lined.
Gills: attached with narrowing end (almost free), distant, moderately broad with short and very short additional gills, pinkish-white or pink; flesh is very thin.
Stalk: 4-8 cm long, 0.3-0.7cm thick and slightly enlarged down, fibrous and hollow, pink or purplish-red.
Edibility: not edible.

results.notes:
Cystodermella Harmaja, Crepidotaceae, Agaricales
Small orange-red mushroom with white cottony scales around stalk and along a cap margin
Cap: 1.5-4 cm wide, convex with rolled in margin with some white cottony scales along margin edge when young, then wide convex or almost flat, light orange or brick-red and some fine velvety, sometimes radial grooved. Flesh is thin, white or pinkish-white
Gills: attached, close and narrow; white.
Stalk: 3-5 cm long, 0.4-0.8cm thick, silky and some fibrous and hollow, light orange or reddish-white with white and range remnants of partial veil around a stalk.
Veil: cottony partial veil makes silky hairs or scales around stalk and somewhat as indistinct cottony ring under a cap.
Edibility: published that edible.
Habitat: rather rare kind; single, minor small groups scattered in mossy sites of pine-tree forest.
Season: July – August

results.notes:
Boletus oliveisporus is getting posted again… because this particular collection is heavily reticulated — something I haven’t observed in the past. Other than that, I cannot visually distinguish this collection from other numerous collections of B. oliveisporus I have made in the past in the NJ Pine Barrens.
It’s a beautiful species with exceptionally dense flesh, and it always comes without a single larval tunnel. Though Texas Mushrooms: A Field Guide by S. & V. Metzler reports this species as edible, I am still waiting for avid bolete consumers to report on the edibility of this profuse blue-stainer.

results.notes:
Found while backpacking in the southern Sierras. Several of these boletes were encountered growing in an almost pure Lodgepole Pine forest (elev 9,300 ft). The largest of these had a cap that was well over 10 cm across, dry, and dusky brown. The pore surface was bright yellow, and when cut open, A slow-forming blue bruising appeared. The stipe had a clear reticulation pattern. It also housed a fairly dense colony of fly larvae. Based on its location and the features I’ve described, I believe this may be B. edulis, but the blue bruising seems at odds with what I’ve found. I’m hoping that those more knowledgeable than I might add their two cents worth.

Location … Lat 37.160057, Lon -119.066981

results.notes:
I’ve come across similar colonies of black, tiny, polyporicolous bristles inhabiting F. pinicola and other conks across the US, first at a Key Council Meeting (Observation 220002), then in the Sierras (observation forthcoming). They’re always with a yellow Hypocrea, too, just like here. I never got past Ophiostomataceae with any of them (though Josh Birkebak is culturing some California material at the time of writing). Of course, John Plischke had not one, but two names, given his determination that the bristles actually come in orange and black, and represent two different species.

Cystolepiota Singer
Cap: 15-25 mm wide, broadly convex up to flat, dull dirty yellow, light brownish-yellow or coffee with milk, concentric colored with outer reddish-brown ring when old; remnants of veil along margin.
Gills: almost free (attached with pinching out end), close and narrow; light orange-yellow when old
Veil: membranous, white (remnants on gills).
Stalk: 4-7cm long, 0.3-0.5 mm thick; light dirty orange, fibrous and hollow when old.
Edibility: no data, too small.
Habitat: rare small group on soil with pine-tree needles in pine-tree forest with some deciduous trees.
Season: July – August
